thread.title: Glencore slashes zinc production and Australian jobs
thread.title_full: Glencore slashes zinc production and Australian jobs

author: Peter Ker
title: Glencore slashes zinc production and Australian jobs
text:
Glencore is set to reduce its global zinc production by more than 30 per cent under a plan that will see one Australian mine close and production from two others reduced.
The news means the Lady Loretta zinc mine near Mt Isa will be the second Australian zinc mine to close in the space of a few months, after Hong Kong listed miner MMG revealed last week that the Century zinc mine had come to the end of its working life.
It is unclear how many Australian jobs will be lost, but mines in South Africa and Kazakhstan will also be affected.
Glencore's move is designed to bolster zinc prices, which were expected by many pundits to be strong in 2015, but have slumped by 28 per cent over the past year to be trading at five-year lows. The company's McArthur River and George Fisher mines will remain open but will scale back output, with Glencore's global zinc operations reducing mine out put by 500,000 tonnes.
Advertisement "This decision will ensure that our zinc operations are sustainable well into the future," said Glencore in a statement.
MMG's Century zinc operation is in the same broader region of Queensland as Glencore's Lady Loretta, and Century was believed to provide close to 4 per cent of world zinc supply.
"Completion of mining at century is a considerable factor in the shrinking of global supply of zinc," said MMG's chief operations manager Marcelo Bastos last week.
Glencore's Australian zinc mines collectively produced 394,000 tonnes of zinc in concentrates during the first half of 2015. The division had adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation of $US209 million in the six months to June 30.
MMG is already preparing to replace Century, and submitted plans for expansion of its Dugald River zinc and lead mine to federal regulators earlier this week.
